Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Rodrigo Trevino is "Teichmuller dynamics in infinite genus." The host institution for the fellowship is Cornell University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. John Smillie.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was about flat surfaces of infinite genus and translation flows on them. If you have a polygon with an even number of sides such that there are pair of sides which are parallel and of the same length, then a flat surface is the geometric object you get when you glue a side of such a polygon with another which is parallel to it and of the same length. If you were to put an ant on this surface and make it walk in a straight line indefinitely, we would wonder where the straight line path would take it. The study of translation flows on flat surfaces is about this question and it relates the complexity of the path taken by the and with the geometry of the surface.


My project was about playing this game with a polygon with infinitely many sides. This gets tricky, but it can be well defined. A lot is known for flat surfaces obtained from polygons with finitely many sides, but there is no nice theory for flat surfaces of infinite type, that is, for flat surfaces made from polygons with infinitely many sides. The intellectual merit of this project was that we advanced out understanding on this, and realized that as long as our polygon has finite area it resembles a lot the case of polygons for finite sides. But we also found things that do not happen for the polygons with finitely many sides. The way one studies these surfaces is by deforming them: by stretching and pulling the surface by an infinite amount, hidden essential geometric structures tell us what will happen with the ant's path. This tool is also used for polygons with finitely many sides. What seems to be emerging is a unified theory that not only explains the behavior for a large class of polygons with infinitely many side, but that includes the case of polygons with finitely many sides.
